awd_titl_txt: CNS Core: Small: Collaborative: Coalescent Computing - New Theory, Mechanism and Platform for Adaptive Edge Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
By moving computation to the edge of the Internet, the emerging edge computing model promises to reduce application response time, improve user experience, save bandwidth cost, and enhance data privacy. This project will establish a new edge-computing theory called coalescent computing, where each application program runs on an integrated virtual computing system, consisting of resources from both edge devices and the cloud, which jointly support application execution according to run-time conditions. The proposed research will establish a novel framework of edge-cloud resource sharing, explore various implementation mechanisms, deploy a hardware platform for experimental studies, develop software tools to transform existing applications to their coalescent-computing versions, and carry out two case studies. Its objective is to enable user applications to seamlessly overcome the resource limitation of edge devices, while keeping the benefits of low response time, communication reduction, and data privacy that edge computing promises.

This work addresses the pressing need for a generic theory of adaptive edge computing, with concrete implementation mechanisms that allow existing applications to take advantage of edge computing without complete re-design. The proposed coalescent-computing framework and its software tools offer a convenient way of transforming existing application code into distributed software with enhanced performance, response time, robustness and scalability, which all contribute to better user experience. The integrated theoretical and experimental research will advance our understanding of modern edge-computing systems. All software tools developed from this project will be made open-source to help stimulate other related research. The project also includes an education plan that introduces edge computing into undergraduate/graduate courses, recruits from under-represented student groups, and helps in club activities at the local high school.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We mainly focus on the research of bringing edge intelligence to various IoT and mobile systems like Wi-Fi indoor tracking and object imaging, edge security and privacy, and energy and scalability in low-power wide-area networks. In general, our intellectural contributions and broad impacts include modeling analysis and computational intelligence, applied machine learning and optimization, and system implementation and measurement.


For Wi-Fi sensing, we survey the existing studies related to enhanced wireless sensing with AI. We first develop a model based tracking system to achieve accurate walking velocity estimation. Moreover, we adopt GAN model to generate a Wi-Fi based imaging system which could achieve fine-grained object segmentation in dark and non-line-of-sight scenarios. All these methods are optimized to be able to run on edge servers.


For edge security and privacy, we develop a speaking-pravicy protection system using machine learning masking technique and ultra-sound non-linearity effect. In addition, we propose a fine-grained client selection model for federated learning to improve the global model accuracy and convergence time simmultaneously. We implement the prototypes on mobile devices and edge servers.


For low-power wide-area networks, we first study the link model and coverage problem. We develop a Bi-LSTM model based path loss estimator revealing the relationship between path loss and different types of landcovers. Then, we measurement the coverage performance and localizability in an urban deployment. Moreover, we develop a new machine learning based physical-layer decoder to improve the communication distance and energy efficiency. Furthermore, we propose new physical-layer and MAC-layer protocols by embracing non-linear chirps to enhance the collision resolving ability, thus improving the network scalability. We summarize existing studies in a survey from the aspects of network stack. We implement both hardware and software to our system evaluation.


We have publish total 11 papers on ACM MobiCom, USNIX NSDI, ACM SenSys, ACM Computing Survey, IEEE INFOCOM, IEEE ICNP, IEEE SECON, IEEE/IFIP DSN under the support of this award. Our work NELoRa won the Best Paper Award of ACM SenSys 2021.
